summary.label:
MDLA is a new kind of fashion magazine - a fashion magazine designed for how we consume fashion online today.

Many of us born in an online generation can only sigh in nostalgia at the glamour and wonder of print fashion magazines from the early 2000s. As the world moved online, the once iconic fashion media companies failed to evolve - they gave us lazy pdfs to browse on slow and buggy e-readers as Inst*gr*m took over to give us the fast immersive content we wanted. Their disinterest in the preservation of beauty online is clear and it’s time we had a new medium to explore and appreciate fashion for fashion’s sake. MDLA is an experiment to revive the glory of early fashion media re-imagined through powerful online media technology from present day.

Our first iteration MDLA Runway brings you a variety of powerful features you’d expect from a modern fashion runway viewer:

* Intuitive Interface - Flip through runway looks with a simple swipe or drag. Jump through to your favorite designer’s early years with just a tap and slide. No endless scroll, no ads, no interruptions

* Powerful search - Search for your favorite collections down to their specific year and season. Find archive collections by your favorite designers from their early years and from labels they previously worked at. Don’t worry about typos or using shorthands - we know what you mean :)

* Lightning fast - Browse high resolution look images from the runway loaded in a flash of a second

* 3D Showcase - Play around with high resolution 3D captures of rare archive “grail” pieces complete with added context from its rich fashion history and references from its original collection for you to explore and learn

* Immersive Editorials - Explore our selection of hand-curated stories of iconic archive pieces, profiles of in vogue runway designers, lost fashion techniques and striking editorial campaigns

Our catalog features thousands of collections dating back to the early 90s from the most iconic names in fashion
Browse the archives from your favorite labels: Dior - Gucci - Louis Vuitton - Prada - Balenciaga - Saint Laurent - Margiela
As well as your favorite designers: Raf Simons - Rick Owens - Tom Ford - Alexander McQueen - Hedi Slimane - Virgil Abloh - Issey Miyake

Coming soon: 
- Create a moodboard of your favorite runway looks and share with friends
- Section to browse latest fashion week collections (eg: nyfw 2023)
- Support for iPad

MDLA is for high fashion followers, meticulous moodboard makers, archive fashion collectors, y2k fashion magazine enjoyers, small town gossip girl lovers, vintage fashion shoppers, aesthetics respecters, ‘it’ girls, clout guys, connoisseurs, hobbyists, tasteful amateurs and most importantly, you :)

La Civiltà Cattolica è la più antica di tutte le riviste italiane ancora attive. E' stata fondata a Napoli e il primo numero è stato stampato il 6 aprile 1850. I suoi redattori sin dalla fondazione sono tutti gesuiti.
La Civiltà Cattolica è aperta a tutti i settori culturali: dalla storia alla sociologia, dall’economia alla politica, dalla cultura digitale alla letteratura, dalle scienze al cinema. dalla teologia alla filosofia. E' attenta al mondo contemporaneo come anche a una lettura dei grandi eventi del passato.
Sin dall’editoriale del primo fascicolo del 1850 ha interpretato così la propria «cattolicità»: «Una Civiltà cattolica non sarebbe cattolica, cioè universale, se non potesse comporsi con qualunque forma di cosa pubblica». E’ questo dunque lo spirito della rivista: comprendere come essere cattolici oggi significhi anche essere aperti al mondo, alle culture e a ogni dimensione pubblica. La Civiltà Cattolica conserva invariato il suo particolare rapporto di sintonia con la Santa Sede, che fa parte della sua identità.
La rivista esce il primo e il terzo sabato del mese (24 quaderni l’anno per complessive 2.500 pagine).
Leggi ogni quindici giorni La Civiltà Cattolica su iPad e iPhone. Puoi comprare un numero o abbonarti per un anno. È gratis per chi è già abbonato alla rivista tramite il sito.

Founded in 1999, The Chap takes a satirical look at the modern world through the eyes of an old-fashioned English gentleman. The Chap seeks to maintain decorum, standards and, above all, correct dress, and it goes about this by celebrating the great dandies and gentlemen of the past, as well as casting a critical eye over the rather disappointing dress habits of today. 

Readers are invited to send their photos in for a sartorial assessment and these are reproduced in the “Am I Chap?” section. Elsewhere, one may read interviews with notable living Chaps such as Chris Eubank, Sir Roger Moore, Adam Ant and Donald Sinden. 

The principal gentlemanly pursuits are also given coverage: Gambling at the horses; Grooming (with particular emphasis on moustache cultivation); Cricket (written by Wisden regular Steve Pittard); Drinking (especially cocktails); Dressing Up (in which every sartorial detail, from waistcoats to slippers to pocket watches, is covered). The Chap also features an in-house butler, who is on hand to answer all your queries of a socio-sartorial nature. 

Whether you truly want to adopt the lifestyle of the dandy or the gentleman, or simply wish to keep yourself informed of the latest developments in cravat usage and pipe tobaccos, 
The Chap is the only British publication entirely devoted to celebrating the arts of the gentleman.
